Chapter 5, Part 3: The King's Discussion, Part 3
The king said:
Great Master!
How many dharmas must a Dharma-practicing king who practices non-negligence possess in order to be called a Dharma-practicing king?
He replied:
Great King!
By accomplishing ten dharmas, one is called a Dharma-practicing king.
What are the ten?
First, accomplishing one's own nature;
Second, having propriety in one's retinue;
Third, accomplishing wisdom;
Fourth, always diligently practicing;
Fifth, respecting the Dharma;
Sixth, being fierce and sharp;
Seventh, having abundant kindness;
Eighth, being well-versed in worldly practices;
Ninth, being able to endure various sufferings;
Tenth, not grasping inverted dharmas.
Great King, you should know!
The king who is accomplished in his own nature has two kinds of meritorious accomplishments:
First, princes, ministers, elders, householders, city dwellers, and villagers all love and respect the king;
Second, he is free from all kinds of illnesses.
Great King, you should know!
The king who has propriety in his retinue also has two kinds of meritorious accomplishments:
First, in the matters the king undertakes, they each compete to accomplish them without the king having to worry;
Second, they are careful not to violate the king's laws.
Great King, you should know!
The king who is accomplished in wisdom also has two kinds of meritorious accomplishments:
First, he skillfully knows skillful means and relies on the Dharma to protect beings well;
Second, in matters he wishes to undertake, he can know them himself and does not rely on others to do them.
Great King, you should know!
The king who is always diligent and vigorous also has two kinds of meritorious accomplishments:
First, all treasuries and storehouses are filled;
Second, there are no enemies or thieves, and they dwell happily and peacefully.
Great King, you should know!
The Dharma King who is respected also has two kinds of meritorious accomplishments:
First, always practicing all wholesome dharmas without rest;
Second, being able to transform sentient beings with evil conduct.
Great King, you should know!
The fierce and sharp king also has two kinds of meritorious accomplishments:
First, being able to quickly fulfill whatever matters he desires in his mind;
Second, whatever matters he wishes to do after giving rise to the mind, he accomplishes in accordance with the Dharma without much deliberation.
Great King, you should know!
The king who is thick with kindness also has two kinds of meritorious accomplishments:
First, the retinue delights in the king;
Second, the ministers and all the people have faith and respect for the king.
Great King, you should know!
The king who skillfully understands the worldly practices also has two kinds of meritorious accomplishments:
First, he is able to know sentient beings with evil conduct and those with good conduct;
Second, the king should obtain things from the people without causing loss.
Great King, you should know!
The king who is able to endure all suffering also has two kinds of meritorious accomplishments:
First, he is able to fulfill the affairs he desires to carry out as a king;
Second, he is not afraid of various suffering and distressing matters.
Great King, you should know!
The king who does not grasp inverted dharmas also has two kinds of meritorious accomplishments:
First, he is able to advance towards the superior path himself;
Second, he always does not part from good and virtuous friends.
Great King, you should know!
One who accomplishes these ten kinds of merits is called one who accomplishes the practice of the Dharma-practicing king.
The king said:
Great Master!

Having accomplished these ten kinds of merits, one is called a Dharma-practicing king. If there is a rebellious king in the country, with the four divisions of troops, who fights with the Dharma-practicing king over the territory, and if a foreign king comes to invade and wants to engage in a great battle, gathering the four divisions of troops all present, how should the Dharma-practicing king fight with them?
He replied:
Great King!
The Dharma-practicing king should contemplate and employ three strategies in the three periods of time to enter the battle and fight.
What are the three periods of time?
They are the time of initial entry, the time of middle entry, and the time of final entry.
Great King, you should know!
When first wanting to enter and employ strategies, the Dharma-practicing king, if he sees the rebellious king, at that time further contemplates three kinds of things:
First, he contemplates whether the troops and horses of the rebellious king are equal to his own or will surpass him;
If we fight with them, both sides will be harmed and there will be no benefit.
If they defeat us, they will live and we will die.
Having thought like this, one should seek out the close friends and good acquaintances of the rebellious king and reconcile them to end this conflict.

Second, a king who practices the Dharma, seeing that the rebellious king has equal or superior power to his own, should think to himself that he should not fight but should offer them wealth to seek the end of the conflict.

Third, if he sees that the rebellious king has many troops, retinue, allies, and the fourfold army of elephants, horses, chariots, and infantry, and his power is superior, although the king who practices the Dharma has few troops, he can use skillful means to show a great courage and invincibility, causing the rebellious king to give rise to a frightened mind to end the conflict. This is called the three kinds of skillful means to be contemplated during the first period.
Great King, you should know!
If these three things - relatives, gifts, and fear - cannot resolve the conflict, the righteous king will then give rise to three thoughts before entering the battle.
What are the three?

First, he thinks, This rebellious king has no compassion. He kills living beings himself and does not stop others from killing. I will now prevent such killing. This is the first thought to protect all beings.
Second, he thinks, I will use skillful means to subdue the rebellious king, and my soldiers and horses will not fight.
Third, he thinks, I will use skillful means to capture him alive, binding him without killing him.

Having given rise to these three kinds of compassionate thoughts, he then arrays the four divisions of his troops, distributes the soldiers and horses, proclaims the orders, selects the soldiers and divides them into three ranks. Among the upper rank there are upper, middle, and lower. The most valiant of the upper rank are placed in the front, followed by the second rank of strong soldiers, and the upper rank of the strongest soldiers and horses are placed on both sides to protect the infantry and prevent them from becoming fearful.
The king who practices the Dharma is in the middle of the army, together with the most valiant of the elephant, horse, chariot, and infantry troops. In this way he enters the battle.
Why is this?
There are five things that can cause a great army to advance without retreating.
What are the five?
First, the king is ashamed;
second, the king is afraid;
third, he takes the king's intention;
fourth, he causes the soldiers behind him to be fearless;
Fifth, it causes one to repay the kindness of the king, according to one's ability and position, without retreating, and to bravely engage in battle.
Great King, you should know!

When a king who practices the Dharma uses this skillful means to enter the battlefield and engage in battle, although he may kill sentient beings at that time, that king will incur a slight and minor offense, not a definite one, and can eliminate it through repentance.
Why is this?

Because that king who practices the Dharma, in order to enter the battle, first generates three kinds of compassionate thoughts, and although he commits this evil, he incurs a slight and minor offense, not a definite one.
Great King, you should know!

In order to protect the Å›ramaá¹‡as and the Dharma of the Å›ramaá¹‡as, to protect his wife, children, clan, and acquaintances, that king who practices the Dharma is able to give up his own body and possessions. Because of this, that king who practices the Dharma obtains immeasurable blessings.
Great King, you should know!

If it is for the protection of the country and the sustenance of the people, and an army is raised to fight, at that time the king should first give rise to the above three minds, and order the general to strictly follow the king's instructions. Those who fight in this way will have merit and no sin.
The king said:
Great Master!
How many kinds of thoughts does a king who practices the Dharma give rise to, and how can he always protect all sentient beings in this way?
He replied:
Great King!
A king who practices the Dharma gives rise to eight kinds of thoughts towards all sentient beings.
What are the eight?
First, he thinks of all sentient beings as if they were his own children;
Second, he thinks of sentient beings who engage in evil conduct as if they were sick children;
Third, he always thinks of suffering sentient beings and gives rise to a mind of great compassion;
Fourth, he thinks of sentient beings who experience supreme bliss and gives rise to a mind of joy;
Fifth, he thinks of sentient beings who are enemies and gives rise to the thought of protecting them from wrongdoing;
Sixth, he is able to think of sentient beings who are friends and gives rise to the thought of covering and protecting them;
Seventh, they are able to give rise to the thought of medicine towards possessions;
Eighth, they are able to give rise to the thought of no-self towards their own bodies.
Great King, you should know!
Those who think of all sentient beings as their children give rise to two kinds of thoughts:
First, they are able to prevent evil like parents thinking of their children and protecting them from harm;
Second, they always do not abandon the compassionate mind towards all sentient beings.
Great King, you should know!
Those who think of sentient beings who engage in evil conduct as sick children give rise to two kinds of thoughts:
First, they are able to endure like a good doctor being scolded by a worldly sick person, and the good doctor does not give rise to a hateful mind;
Second, they cultivate such a mind in order to eliminate all faults and misconduct.
Great King, you should know!
Those who think of sentient beings who experience suffering and give rise to a greatly compassionate mind give rise to two kinds of thoughts:
First, they are able to rescue and relieve their suffering in all urgent difficulties;
Second, they are able to bestow supreme peace and bliss.
Great King, you should know!
Those who give rise to a joyful mind towards sentient beings who experience pleasure give rise to two kinds of thoughts:
First, they are able to not give rise to greedy thoughts towards the wealth and possessions of others;
Second, they do not give rise to jealous thoughts towards the wealth and nobility of others.
Great King, you should know!
Those who give rise to the thought of protecting faults towards sentient beings who are enemies give rise to two kinds of thoughts:
First, they always think of severing the causes of faults and distancing themselves from enemies;
Second, they are able to give rise to a friendly mind towards sentient beings who are enemies, let alone those who are not enemies.
Great King, you should know!
Those who give rise to the thought of covering and protecting towards sentient beings who are friends give rise to two kinds of thoughts:
First, they think of making friends firm and solid;
Second, they think of causing all sentient beings to not give rise to resentment and hatred.
Great King, you should know!
Those who give rise to the thought of medicine towards possessions give rise to two kinds of thoughts:
First, having desires but not engaging in sexual misconduct;
Second, being able to enjoy forms, smells, tastes, and touches in the world without giving rise to craving or attachment.
Great King, you should know!
Those who have no self-view in their own bodies give rise to two kinds of thoughts:
First, going to the side of a Å›ramaá¹‡a or a greatly wise person to ask about the Dharma;
Second, hearing the Dharma and practicing as taught.
Great King, you should know!

Because the Dharma King always contemplates these eight dharmas, he does not seek for sustenance, yet people in the world naturally offer precious and unusual things that are not found in the country, filling his storehouses to overflowing;
And those non-dharma evil kings in the world who whip the populace and oppress them for money do not have even one of these [eight dharmas].
Great King, you should know!
The Dharma King who practices these eight dharmas, in his activities, the years, seasons, days, months, stars, and lunar mansions are always auspicious.
All non-humans and evil ghosts seeking an opportunity will not be able to find one.

In that country, the wind and rain will be timely, the five grains will be abundant, the people will be well-fed and have no thoughts of hunger or thirst, and all insects, birds, mice, dragons, hail, and other harmful things in the world will all cease.
If there are enemies and thieves in that country, they will all suffer according to their own karmic offenses, and their karma will be exhausted and cease according to their own karma.
Great King, you should know!

If a Dharma-practicing king can thus protect all beings and the world of vessels, he will not betray all worldly beings, all good practitioners, wise people, sages, and no being will be able to reproach him.
Why is this?

Great King, you should know!
If a king who practices goodness like this should die, he will be reborn in the heavens and experience the wonderful pleasures of the gods.
